content.title: Blended Finance
content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 3 | Lesson 3

content.text: Lesson 3 Overview

This lesson delves into blended finance as a strategy for leveraging public and philanthropic capital to attract private sector investments in renewable energy projects. It explores how concessional finance, which provides funding on more favorable terms, plays a critical role in de-risking projects and making them more attractive to investors. The lesson also covers examples of successful blended finance structures, such as public-private partnerships, and explains how these models can be applied to scale up renewable energy in emerging markets.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: concessional finance
concepts.body: Concessional finance refers to loans or financial assistance provided on terms significantly more generous than market rates, often including lower interest rates or extended repayment periods, aimed at supporting development projects in low-income countries.

concepts.title: subordinated debt√™
concepts.body: Subordinated debt is a type of loan or bond that ranks below other debts in terms of claims on assets or earnings in the event of liquidation or bankruptcy, meaning it is repaid after senior debts.

concepts.title: syndicated lending
concepts.body: Syndicated lending is a loan provided by a group of lenders, typically banks, who work together to fund a single borrower, sharing the risk and resources involved.

content.title: Part 1: What Is Blended Finance

content.text: Blended finance is a critical mechanism for mobilizing private sector investment into high-risk, high-impact sustainable energy projects in developing countries. It employs concessional lending to de-risk investments, thereby "crowding in" investment from commercial funders. By strategically combining concessional funding from public sources with private capital, blended finance mitigates risks and enhances the financial viability of projects that would otherwise struggle to attract private investment. This is particularly significant as estimations show that around 60% of clean energy finance for Emerging Markets and Developing Economies (EMDEs), excluding China, must come from the private sector. This private sector contribution is expected to rise to USD 0.9-1.1 trillion annually by the early 2030s, up from USD 135 billion today.

Blended finance leverages concessional funds from donors and philanthropic sources to de-risk high-impact activities in priority areas such as climate action. This approach expands the pool of bankable projects and attracts private investment. Blended finance operations aim to achieve both commercial sustainability and viability. A key measure of blended finance’s effectiveness is its “leverage,” defined as the ratio of commercial financing (from Development Finance Institutions (DFIs), sponsors, and private financiers) to the amount of concessional funds. For example, based on the International Finance Corporation's (IFC) experience, USD 1 of concessional donor funding has leveraged, on average, nearly USD 7 of additional finance, including USD 3-4 from IFC’s loan funds and USD 3-4 from commercial third-party capital.

Similarly, co-financing syndicated lending can mobilize about USD 7 of bank credit for each USD 1 provided by multilateral development banks (MDBs). In climate transactions, the leverage ratio is often higher (USD 1 to USD 10), reflecting the relatively large project finance structures and significant deployment in middle-income countries, which have lower country risks and can attract more commercial finance. At its core, blended finance leverages various instruments to de-risk investments. Guarantees and insurance are among the most effective tools, providing coverage against political, regulatory, and currency risks. These instruments lower the cost of capital and enhance investor confidence, particularly in risk-prone environments. For instance, guarantees from MDBs significantly reduce the perceived risk, making projects more attractive to private investors. Additionally, subordinated debt is often used, with public entities providing subordinated loans that absorb initial losses, offering a security cushion for private investors. This improves the risk-return profile of projects, making them more appealing to private capital. Technical assistance and capacity-building initiatives are also essential in project preparation, helping to enhance bankability by supporting design, feasibility studies, and risk assessment.

Public-private partnerships (PPPs) further illustrate the collaborative potential of blended finance. By combining resources and expertise from both the public and private sectors, PPPs can undertake large-scale projects that might otherwise be too daunting for individual entities. This collaborative model leverages the strengths of the public sector (e.g., regulatory support and initial funding) and the private sector (e.g., efficiency and innovation), facilitating the implementation of clean energy projects on a larger scale.

content.title: Case Study: Kazakhstan

content.text: UNDP Kazakhstan, in collaboration with local institutions like the "Damu" Entrepreneurship Development Fund JSC, introduced an innovative blended finance approach to address funding gaps essential for advancing a low-carbon development pathway. As part of Kazakhstan's Strategy to achieve carbon neutrality, which prioritizes the gradual transition of Kazakhstan’s electricity sector to alternative and renewable energy sources by 2060, the introduction of renewable energy technologies is essential for both large-scale plants and small and medium-sized enterprises. UNDP with the support of the GEF applied De-Risking Renewable Energy Investment (DREI) methodology to test and implement new support instruments. The aim of this methodology is to target interventions and create a "risk-return" profile that encourages private investment to provide reliable, environmentally friendly, and affordable energy solutions in the country. UNDP financial support instruments helped secure $68 million in private investments to implement 75 green projects. These projects are estimated to reduce and avoid a total of 2,149,821 tons of CO2 equivalent greenhouse gas emissions over their lifecycles. Link: https://www.undp.org/kazakhstan/press-releases/undp-presented-results-project-de-risking-investments-green-energy-sector-kazakhstan

content.title: Part 2: Risk and barriers to commercial investment in Blended Finance

content.text: One of the key determinants for deciding the most appropriate types of blended finance will be the underlying risks and barriers to commercial investment that it is trying to address. Features and barriers to commercial investment that can apply in the case of clean energy investments (and certain other types of investments) include:
Political Risks

Clean energy projects that are highly site-specific – for example, wind, hydroelectric, and solar plants – can be politically and socially sensitive and be exposed to complex land permitting processes. Along with increasing the risk that projects fail to get approval, this can prolong the development phase of projects and delay construction and operation, and therefore delay the point at which investors begin generating returns.
Revenue volatility

The rapid growth and relative inexperience of stakeholders along the clean energy supply chain can result in inaccurate assessments of, and imbalances between, supply and demand. This can be compounded by the long-term horizon of clean energy investments.
Political Risks

Clean energy projects that are highly site-specific – for example, wind, hydroelectric, and solar plants – can be politically and socially sensitive and be exposed to complex land permitting processes. Along with increasing the risk that projects fail to get approval, this can prolong the development phase of projects and delay construction and operation, and therefore delay the point at which investors begin generating returns.
Technology Risk

Project developers and operators may be unfamiliar with a certain clean energy technology, which may create a higher perception of risk and may make it difficult for investors to undertake robust due diligence on potential investments. However, this risk may be reduced if economies of scope have already influenced the perceived attractiveness and maturity of the technology, signaling broader market acceptance and reliability.
Counterparty, off-taker, and transmission line delay risk

This may take the form of weak creditworthiness of local partners, such as power utilities, or dependence of many clean energy projects on parallel infrastructure investment (for example the dependence of renewable power generation projects on grid infrastructure that is completed in time for energy production).
Reputational risk

Investors may be concerned about the sourcing of raw materials and manufacturing of components for clean energy infrastructure, as well as the overall sustainability of infrastructure, for example in the management and recycling of batteries.

content.title: Part 3: What Makes A Perfect Blend?

content.text: All projects using concessional funds must include a rigorous assessment of market failures to support the need for temporary subsidies and evaluate the potential for unlocking development impact. The DFI Working Group on Blended Finance agreed in 2017 to a set of blended finance principles designed to guide all DFI operations involving blended finance.

These principles help ensure that projects have a clearly defined economic rationale for concessional support, use only the minimum concessional funding required to make a project viable, and have a clear path to graduate from temporary concessional support to reach commercial viability.

Scaling the mobilization of commercial capital towards clean energy will require concerted, systematic efforts by beneficiary governments, donors, and the private sector. Having a clear overarching development and by extension, climate objective – for example, sustainable energy access and clean industrial development – as per Principle 1, can help manage commercial investors’ perceptions of risk by giving them confidence that individual projects and investments are part of a wider, determined government strategy. Designing and structuring blended finance in a way that attracts more private sector investment - as per principle 2 by using public or concessional funds to reduce risks or enhance returns, making climate projects more appealing to commercial investors. Projects, and the way they are financed, also need to be determined in large part by local conditions, in line with Principle 3 – for example by being tailored to local capital market conditions – to most effectively tap into commercial capital and help address potential foreign exchange issues most effectively. Establishing strong partnerships and country-led governance structures that bring together beneficiary governments, donors, and the private sector, in line with Principle 4, can also help to align the incentives of commercial investors with beneficiary countries’ wider development and climate objectives.

Finally, the complexity of blended finance is often compounded in the case of the clean energy sector, one feature of which is the presence of untested project developers, technologies, and routes to commercial sustainability; this puts an additional emphasis on the need for effective monitoring and evaluation of results, in line with Principle 5. While blended finance can be an effective mechanism for scaling the mobilization of commercial finance, it is not a panacea. It cannot alone address long-standing barriers to infrastructure investment in emerging markets and developing economies and must come as part of a wider strategy to address macro-level issues – for example, sovereign credit risk and other macroeconomic imbalances, currency instability, and weak local capital markets – as well as sector-specific barriers to commercial investment.

Blended finance should be deployed in a way that supports thcreation of sustainable private markets and is provided together with support to strengthen and create suitable regulatory frameworks that can attract commercial finance and private investments in clean energy projects. Moreover, blended finance may not always be the solution to scaling up the mobilization of commercial finance and given the scarcity of development finance and wider development and climate objectives, its use should be carefully calibrated to maximize its impact.

content.title: Case Study: The CAF-UNDP JET Blended Finance Facility

content.text: Status: under development

Establishing partnerships to structure innovative financial instruments and scale up finance will be essential to deliver the institutional goals proposed by UNDP and the Development Bank of Latin America and the Carribbean (CAF) The objective of this project is to establish the CAF-UNDP Blended Finance Facility to support NDBs and LFIs in LAC to reduce GHG emissions and mobilize and catalyze USD 5 billion from the private sector investment for Just Energy Transition and Bioeconomy by the end of 2028. The facility aims to achieve its objective by: (i) supporting NDBs and LFIs to integrate sustainability into their operations and strategies; (ii) piloting innovative green financial instruments; and (iii) structuring sustainable de risking mechanisms. UNDP will add value providing technical assistance for the following partners and activities: Local financial system: market assessments, portfolio diagnosis, financial strategies, MRV systems, financial instruments, and de-risking mechanisms. National government: enabling conditions, policies and incentives. The private sector: technical support. Public and private dialogues: establishment and coordination of dialogues for financial innovation. The facility will use different financial instruments such as concessional loans, investment grants, grants, carbon finance, and capital markets to structure cutting-edge financial instruments and de-risking mechanisms for JET and Bioeconomy to scale up private finance through NDBs and LFIs. The facility will work with the public sector to create enabling conditions for NDBs and LFIs operations. Public and private dialogues will allow financial innovation to pilot new financial instruments and regulations.

content.title: Key Takeaways
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Subsidies for fossil fuels distort markets, strain public finances, and perpetuate overconsumption, delaying transitions to sustainable energy. Reforming these subsidies is critical to reducing fiscal pressures and advancing clean energy investments.

Examples like Indonesia, Iran, and India demonstrate that gradual subsidy phase-outs, combined with targeted cash transfers and transparent communication, can protect vulnerable populations while freeing up resources for renewable energy and infrastructure development.
Instead of solely relying on emergency measures during price spikes, it is more effective to implement structural changes that reduce the overall demand for fossil fuels.
